para.text: The purpose of this ordinance is to establish a process for the adoption of new Members into the Stockbridge-Munsee Community as authorized under Article III, Section 4, of the Constitution of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community.

The original membership of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community shall consist of all persons eligible and enrolled under the definition of membership contained in Article III, Section 1, 2, and 3 of the Constitution of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community.
Definitions.
"Applicant" refers to a person applying for membership in the Stockbridge-Munsee Community.
"Base Roll" refers to the January 1, 1940 Indian Census Roll of Stockbridge-Munsee Indians taken through the Tomah Indian Agency.
"Blood Quantum" refers to the degree of Stockbridge-Munsee Community Indian blood (degree of Indian blood) required to meet membership criteria.
"Constitution" refers to the Constitution and By-laws of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community adopted in 1937, as amended.
"Department" refers to the Land and Enrollment Department or other such department designated by the Tribal Council.
"Descendant" refers to a person whom is in a direct line of biological descent from an ancestor, as from grandparent to parent to child in a direct descending line.
"Enrollment" refers to the process used to adopt new members of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community and, as applicable, place their names on the Membership Roll.
"Member" refers to any person enrolled in the Stockbridge-Munsee Community who has the privileges and responsibilities of membership.
"Membership Roll" refers to the list of all living persons who are Members of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community.
"Sponsor" refers to a person applying for membership on behalf of another individual, such as a parent, guardian, or other legal representative (e.g., an Indian child welfare worker).
"Tribal Council" or "Council" means the Tribal Council of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community.

section.heading: Establishment Of Membership Committee
section.text: A Membership Committee consisting of seven persons effective March 20, 2001 is hereby established which shall review all applications for adoption and conduct investigations of tribal status, degree of Indian blood and other characteristics of the applicants as it shall deem necessary in determining whether the Applicants should be adopted as Members of the Community, and shall thereupon submit such information to the Council together with recommendations indicating the Committee's approval or disapproval in each case.

para.text: The Membership Committee shall be appointed by the Tribal Council for a period of two years. The Committee shall have only advisory powers and no member shall be at the same time a member of the Council. The recommendations of the Committee shall be made in writing and signed by at least four members of the Committee.

Four terms of the Membership Committee shall run concurrently with the term of the Tribal President. The other three terms of the Membership Committee shall run for two years, but, shall expire on the eve of the October election in years that the Tribal President is not up for election.

Section 44.3 (B) is intended to implement staggered terms for the Membership Committee. Upon the adoption of the 2001 amendment and effective March 2001, the three incumbent Committee Members' terms shall expire on the eve of the October 2001 election, and on the eve of every other October election thereafter. As of March 20, 2001, the four other Committee Members' terms shall expire on the eve of the October 2002 election, and on the eve of every other October election thereafter.

The Stockbridge-Munsee Community recognizes that elders can provide valuable input to the Membership Committee. Therefore, at least two of the Committee Members shall be elders (at least 55 years old), provided that at least two elders seek appointment to the Membership Committee. If elders do not seek appointment, the Membership Committee shall be appointed in accordance with Section 44.3 (B), and without regard to elder status.

The elder terms shall coincide with Section 44.3(B). One elder appointment shall expire on the eve of the October 2001 election, and on the eve of every other October election thereafter. The other elder appointment shall expire on the eve of the October 2002 election, and on the eve of every other October election thereafter.
Tribal Council, by motion at a regularly scheduled Council meeting, reserves the right to remove a Membership Committee member for cause.

Persons identified as Stockbridge-Munsee on the Base Roll shall be deemed to have a Blood Quantum that is full (4/4) Stockbridge-Munsee Indian blood for the purpose of determining whether their Descendants may be adopted as new Members, regardless of the degree of Indian blood specified on the Base Roll.

Persons who are the biological full siblings of Members listed on the Base Roll, even if the sibling is born after January 1, 1940, are also deemed to have a Blood Quantum that is full (4/4) Stockbridge-Munsee Indian blood.
This Section does not change the status of persons referenced on the Base Roll that are not identified as Stockbridge-Munsee.

All persons identified as Stockbridge-Munsee whose name appears on the roll of 1871 and any subsequent roll through the Base Roll, including the roll of 1910, are deemed to have a Blood Quantum that is full (4/4) Stockbridge-Munsee Indian blood for the purpose of determining whether their Descendants may be adopted as new Members, regardless of the degree of Indian blood specified on such rolls.

The use of the Base Roll to determine Blood Quantum for the adoption of new Members does not impact the membership status of persons previously enrolled as Members under Article III, Sections 1, 2 or 3 of the Constitution or of persons previously adopted into membership under this Ordinance, but may affect their Blood Quantum as addressed in Section 44.6 (C)(1).

section.heading: Loss Of Membership
section.text: Provided, that any person whose name appears on the 1871 Stockbridge-Munsee roll or any subsequent roll up to and including the roll of 1910 of the Stockbridge-Munsee Indians of Wisconsin, who has relinquished their membership, or their entitlement to membership, or have been disenrolled for any reason shall not be Members of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community.

section.heading: Eligibility For Adoption As New Member
section.text: Descendants of persons who are enrolled in the Stockbridge-Munsee Community shall be eligible for adoption as new Members, provided such Descendants present acceptable evidence of having a Blood Quantum of one-quarter (1/4) or more degree Stockbridge-Munsee Indian blood.

para.text: Descendants of Members of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community may be enrolled as new members of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community upon approval by the Tribal Council based on the following enrollment process; Provided such Descendants are of one-quarter (1/4) or more Stockbridge-Munsee Indian blood; and, Provided further that such Descendants are not members of any other Indian tribe.
An Applicant, or his/her Sponsor, shall submit a completed application for enrollment to the Department that includes a certified copy of the Applicant's birth certificate.
The Department will review the application materials for completeness and prepare supporting materials including a family tree and a preliminary determination of Blood Quantum.

Once the supporting materials are complete, the Department will forward the application and supporting materials to the Membership Committee to review and make a recommendation on whether the Applicant should be enrolled and, if so, what the Blood Quantum should be. The details of specific applications are discussed in executive session; however, the recommendations on the applications are documented in open session.

The Membership Committee's recommendation will be forwarded to the Tribal Council, who will, by motion in open session, decide whether to approve or deny membership to the Applicant and confirm the Applicant's Blood Quantum.

An Applicant becomes a Member effective as of the date of the Tribal Council's action to approve membership. The execution of supporting paperwork and the Department's entry of the person's name onto the Membership Roll are administrative actions and do not change the date of membership.
Calculation of Blood Quantum.

The Department shall update its membership records to reflect the recalculated Blood Quantum of Members. This recalculation is based on the method outlined in Section 44.4 where persons who were enrolled on or before January 1, 1940, are deemed to have full Stockbridge-Munsee Indian blood as well as the biological full siblings of Members listed on the Base Roll, even if the sibling is born after January 1, 1940.
The Blood Quantum of Applicants will be calculated based on the approach outlined in Section 44.4.
The Department is responsible for maintaining membership records on current and past members, including the Membership Roll.

The Department holds membership records, most particularly protected information such as social security numbers, confidential except to the extent disclosures are necessary for the purpose of governmental operations or are authorized. The minimum amount of information necessary for the purpose will be disclosed as part of any such disclosures.
The Membership Roll is not distributed except as authorized by law or by the Tribal Council.

section.heading: Process To Deny Request For Enrollment

para.text: If the Membership Committee recommends the Tribal Council deny enrollment to an applicant, the following procedure shall apply:
At least two regular Tribal Council meetings are required in order to deny membership.

At a regular Tribal Council meeting, the Tribal Council shall announce, by motion, its intent to deny membership to the named Applicant. For the purpose of this Ordinance, regular Tribal Council meeting has the same meaning as in Chapter 50, Procedures Ordinance.
The Tribal Council Secretary shall than notify the Applicant or, if applicable, the Sponsor that the Tribal Council is considering denying the membership application.
Such notification shall be in writing and shall be served via certified, restricted, return receipt requested.
The notification shall state the following:

"At the ___________(date) regular Tribal Council meeting, Tribal Council made a motion of its intent to deny membership to ___________ (applicant's name). Tribal Council based its decision on _______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________. You have thirty calendar days to respond if you wish to challenge Tribal Council's intent to deny membership. If you do not respond within thirty calendar days, Tribal Council may deny membership to the applicant at its next Regular Tribal Council meeting.

If you chose to contest Tribal Council's intent to deny membership, the applicant, its parent(s), its guardian, or representative must respond in writing to the Tribal Secretary. Your response must be received within thirty calendar days of you receiving this notice. If you are contesting Tribal Council's intent to deny membership, the applicant, its parent(s), its guardian, or representative will have the opportunity to review the copies of the documents that Tribal Council is relying on.

If you are contesting Tribal Council's intent to deny membership, the Tribal Council Secretary will then contact the applicant in order to schedule the membership issue on an upcoming regular Tribal Council meeting agenda. The Tribal Council Secretary will also provide you with the copies of relevant documents that Tribal Council relied on for its intent to deny membership decision."

If the Applicant has not responded to the Tribal Secretary's Section 44.65 (A)(3) notice, then the Tribal Council may take action to deny membership to the Applicant at a regular Tribal Council meeting.

If the Applicant has responded to the Tribal Secretary's notice, then the Tribal Council may not take action to deny membership unless the Applicant or the Sponsor or a designated representative has had an opportunity to present its case to the Tribal Council in Executive Session at a regular Tribal Council meeting.
The Applicant or Sponsor bears the burden of proving that enrollment should not be denied.

Notwithstanding Section 44.65 (A)(5), Tribal Council may take action to deny membership if the Applicant or Sponsor or a designated representative does not attend a Tribal Council meeting within ninety calendar days after responding the Tribal Secretary's Section 44.65 (A)(3) notice.

Nothing in Section 44.65 (A) is intended to limit Tribal Council's authority to consider membership matters to only two Tribal Council meetings, provided that Applicants are provided with the opportunity to respond pursuant the requirements in Section 44.65 (A).
All seven (7) members of the Tribal Council shall be present in order to take action on the final decision to deny membership as outlined in Sections 44.65 (A) (4) and (5) above.
Tribal Council is the final forum to determine Tribal Member eligibility.
A denial of enrollment by the Tribal Council is final.
The Applicant or Sponsor is not permitted to submit a new application unless a material change in the underlying facts or circumstances can be shown.
The recalculation of Blood Quantum due to Section 44.4 (B) would constitute a material change and permit a new application for enrollment.

section.heading: Voluntary Relinquishment Of Membership
section.text: Enrolled Tribal Members may voluntarily relinquish their Tribal membership in accordance with established policies and procedures.

section.heading: Sovereign Immunity
section.text: Nothing in this Ordinance shall provide or be interpreted to provide a waiver of the sovereign immunity of the Stockbridge-Munsee Community, or its governmental officers, agents, employees, or committees.

section.heading: Severability
section.text: If any section or any part thereof, of this Ordinance shall be held invalid or illegal by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of the section or part of the Ordinance shall not be affected and shall remain in full force and effect as though no section, or part thereof, has been declared to be invalid or illegal.

para.text: Membership Ordinance was approved by Council February 20, 1940 and approved by Assistant Secretary Aug. 30, 1940.

para.heading: Ordinance was amended Jan.
para.text: 9, 1949, approved by BIA Jan. 19, 1949, adding Section 8 (became Section 44.7 as of 1995 and renumbered as 44.6 in 2010).
Section 4 (44.4) amended by tribal referendum June 1, 1968, approved by Commissioner of Indian Affairs, April 11, 1969.

Section 6 of original document was deleted by Tribal Resolution 003, September 14, 1971 which began with "A member shall lose his or her membership in the Community upon maintaining a permanent residence away from the Community........." Received by BIA September 16, 1971. Approved by Commissioner on September 28, 1971.
On March 20, 2001, Resolution No. 018-2001, Tribal Council adopted the following amendments:

ul.li: Section 44.1, technical change. The Ordinance incorrectly referred to Sections 11, 2 and 3 of Article III of the Tribal Constitution. The correct sections are 1, 2, and 3 of Article III of the Tribal Constitution.
Section 44.2, expanding the Membership Committee from three to seven members, effective March 20, 2001.

Section 44.3(A), deleted the reference that the Committee Members served "coinciding with the terms of the President of the Council" and changed the number of members who must sign the recommendations to Council from two members to four members to coincide with the seven member committee.
Section 44.3(B) and Section 44.3(B)(1), newly created, establishing staggered terms for the seven member Membership Committee.
Section 44.3(C), newly created, establishing the desirability that two of the Membership Committee be elders.
Section 44.3(C)(1), newly created, establishing that the two elder terms be staggered terms.
Section 44.3(D), newly created, establishing that Membership Committee member can be removed for cause.

Section 44.7(B), newly created, incorporating the majority of the content of a 1985 Tribal Council directive (that was not previously incorporated into the Ordinance) so that the Membership Committee may consider other documents in determining blood degree, in addition to meeting the requirements of Section 44.7(A).

para.text: The March 20, 2001 amendments approved by BIA, April 10, 2001.
Section 44.8 on relinquishment of membership newly created by Tribal Council on October 1, 2002 by Resolution No. 055-02. Approved by BIA on October 18, 2002.

Sections 44.7 (C) and (D), establishing process for denial of membership; 44.9, Sovereign Immunity; and 44.10, Severability, newly created by Tribal Council on September 7, 2004 by Resolution No. 045-04. Approved by BIA on November 8, 2004.
On July 20, 2010, Resolution No. 055-10, Tribal Council adopted the following amendments:

ul.li: Deleting Section 44.6 (requiring a referendum for adoption of new members); and
Renumbering 44.7; 44.8; 44.9; 44.10 (based on deletion of prior 44.6); and
Creating new Section 44.6 (C) (5) (a); and
Renumbering Section 44.6 (C) (5) (c); and
Creation new Section 44.6 (D); and
Renumbering Sections 44.6 (E)

para.text: The July 20, 2010 amendments approved by the acting BIA Superintendent on August 13, 2010.

On October 5, 2010, Tribal Council made an administrative correction to necessitate their original intent by adding the words "take action on the final decision to deny membership as outlined in Sections 44.6 (C) (4) and (5) above" to Section 44.6 (D).

A referendum question asking whether tribal members supported changing the Membership Ordinance to use 1940 as a baseline to establish blood quantum for adoption of new members was on the ballot of the October 12, 2019 general election. The vote was 313 in support and 157 in opposition to the change.

On December 3, 2019, by Resolution No. 18-20, the Tribal Council adopted amendments to Chapter 44 to modify the calculation of Blood Quantum for the adoption of new Members by establishing 1940 baseline for the calculation of Blood Quantum, clarifying the enrollment process used to adopt new Members, and making other administrative updates. The specific amendments are as follows:

ul.li: Headings added to the ordinance sections.

Section 44.1 amended to add new subsections (A) and (C) clarifying the purpose of the ordinance is to address how new Members are adopted into the Tribe, as well as identify the authority under the Constitution and provide definitions. Prior language under Section 44.1 now under subsection (B), which was clarified.

Section 44.2 amended to delete reference to Membership Committee accepting applications for adoption since accepted by Land and Enrollment Department and add language that Committee reviews all applications.

Section 44.4 amended to add new subsections (A) and (C) establishing new baseline of 1940 roll for calculating Blood Quantum and modifying prior language referencing other rolls to clarify that members identified in them treated as if full blood as well. Prior language was amended and designated as subsection (B).
Section 44.45 established as new Section. Language unchanged; had previously been part of Section 44.4.
Section 44.5 amended to clarify that it establishes eligibility criteria for adoption as a new Member of the Tribe.

Section 44.6 amended to add new subsections (A)(1)-(5); (B); (C); (D); and (E). These provisions describe the process used to enroll new Members; calculate Blood Quantum; and address membership records. Language that previously had been (A) modified to add reference to enrollment process described in subsections 1-5. Language previously in subsection (B) about other documents that may be considered deleted since no longer relevant due to the new 1940 baseline approach toward Blood Quantum. Language about denial of enrollment that had been in subsection (C) moved to new section.

Section 44.65 is new section with materials that had previously been subsection 44.6 (C). No substantive changes (some wording changes based on definitions and cross references updated) other than to add a new subsection (D) identifying that a denial of enrollment is final unless there is a material change in circumstances.
Section 44.8 amended to clarify the ordinance does not waive the Tribe's sovereign immunity.

para.text: The 2019 amendments were _____________ by the BIA on _________________.
